pr_title: Issue #1742 - Added forEach to ScannerBase. Added test in ScannerIT.

timeline.message: Issue #1742 - Added forEach method in ScannerBase. Added test in ScannerIT.

timeline.author: keith-turner

timeline.message: Issue #1742 - Removed test in ScannerIT. Added standalone ScannerBase test.

timeline.author: ctubbsii

timeline.bodyText: I don't think most (if any) of these should be class members. They can be local variables in the test case.
timeline.author: ctubbsii
ctubbsii

timeline.bodyText: Should verify mock objects at the end of the test.
timeline.author: ctubbsii

timeline.bodyText: This can be done in the test. It doesn't need to be here, unless it's common code for multiple tests.
timeline.author: ctubbsii
ctubbsii

replies.bodyText: Later comment makes this suggestion unnecessary. The class isn't needed at all.
replies.author: ctubbsii

timeline.author: ctubbsii

timeline.bodyText:
After simplifying a bit myself, it seems like that the forEach concept is being tested on the ForEachTester object, but the test is never actually calling the ScannerBase.forEach method... which is the method that this test case should be covering.
It would be better if ScannerBase was a partial mock... overriding iterator() (as you've already done), but leaving the implementation of forEach alone, and calling that in your test. The ForEachTester class doesn't seem necessary at all. It can simply be deleted.
timeline.author: ctubbsii

timeline.message: Issue #1742 - Removed mocks. Created ScannerBase subclass for test.

timeline.bodyText: Extending List forces you to add implementations for a bunch of methods. You can just implement ScannerBase, and have a constructor that takes a map, which itself is easily constructed, using Map.of(...). MockScanner's iterator() method can just return map.entrySet().iterator().
timeline.author: ctubbsii

timeline.message: Issue #1742 - Removed List/added Map to test object.
